newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish airline Centennial ceases operations.
newsitem.headline: Spanish airline Centennial ceases operations.

text.p: Spanish charter airline Centennial ceased operations and filed for voluntary bankruptcy last Friday, crippled by debts of around 3.5 billion pesetas ($27 million), a spokeswoman said on Monday.

The carrier had been struggling for some months until last week Irish leasing company GPA impounded one of its aircraft and the British and Spanish civil aviation authorities both withdrew its licences.
Company officials are still assessing the exact amount of the debt, which is approximately 3.5 billion pesetas, the spokesman said. Centennial's assets are of minimal value.
Its five McDonnell Douglas MD-83 aircraft are all leased from various lessors, and it was 13 days late on payments to GPA, she added.
The company, which has 250 employees, is majority-owned by director general Tomas Cano and its clients included many of the major European tour operators such as Thomson and Alpitour.
A company official said only last month that revenues were around 12.5 billion pesetas ($98 million) a year and that the airline made a modest profit.
